Time to update this review. A substantial amount of work has been done since its early access release. Now this game is quite fun to play for extended periods of time. There is a lot to explore, quests available from townsfolk, random dungeons, monsters roaming the land. It is a very fun free-roaming sandbox arpg. Grand Theft Fable?

The gameplay is pretty basic 3rd person arpg. Not isometric like Diablo et al, but presented in an over- the-shoulder 3rd person perspective like Fable(or GTA). You can be nice and help people, or you can steal from everybody and be a murderous thug. I am sure that at some point a story will be added, but right now it is more of a free-roaming sandbox.

The combat is slightly loose, and could be tightened up a little bit. For the most part combat works as expected. Sometimes it is a little hard to time strikes perfectly. This is not bad enough to be a serious problem,  just a minor quibble with the gameplay which I'm sure can be adjusted. Even if they leave the combat as is, I'd still be happy with the game. But I could be  happier.

I especially appreciate the graphics, which are slightly cute and cartoonish, yet stunning at the same time with the settings maxed out at 1080p.

Just wanted to give my first impressions. Where to start :-).
Firstly game enviroments feels very much like Cube world more than minecraft in my opinion. The terrain is still somewhat disjointed in places  e.g uneven terrain especially roads (unlike Cubeworlds beautiful smoothness in creating terrain and especially roads through the terrain). The terrain has some great effects when travelling from biome to biome (much better than Cube world in my opinion). Overall still really enjoying the terrain and just wandering about (which I did a lot in Cube world). Towns seem to be in the game but other than the  starting town (with walls around it) the other towns just seem barren by comparrison (just a few  buildings scattered quite far from one another  and  no road going  through them in most cases.  I hope the developers plan to tweak and add  more to the current towns on roads and make them unique in each biome (eg different looking buildings - e.g. in forrest roofs made out of leaves, plains roofs made out of hay etc......). Gameplay is interesting. It is somewhat basic at this time (although being an Alpha I expect that will hopefully change for the better). Finding items out in the wild is very limited at this time (the best thing I found randomly was a Magnificent Key). Most of the time you will find chests with no keys or barrels filled with fruit (very useful). Keys in particular seem very hard to find (too hard in my opinion). You can level up as you explore/fight although the effects do not seem to do much at this time (im my opinion). And yes I know it does raise my health  as I level up. Also have not found any major weapon upgrades other that armor shoulder pads at this time. one time found a spellbook (from a dead friendly AI) and could not figure how to use it, and  also a glowing green staff.  (most of my time was exploring anyway so not important). I feel this game has alot of potential like Cube world. I hope they are able to continue to work on this jem. The graphics look great although this game seems to struggle on my system (i5- 3550,  8gb ram and a 295 GTX graphics card). Make sure you turn down AA expecially. I was having a slide show when trying to run on Ultra with 4x AA enabled. Much better with Medium with 2x AA enabled although I does still seem to chug at times (obviously being an Alpha I also understand that tuning with come later - maybe at the  beta stage). Basically at the end of  the  day I do not regret purchasing this game at all and really looking forward to what they do next. I have already read on the work on the terrain generation (great) and I hope they can flesh the game out (more weapons,armors etc..) and would like to see some variations on  monsters for specific biomes (e.g. monsters in the snow biome will not be seen in the jungle biome for instance). Great job to the developers. I do not regreat investing my $14.95 purchase price towards supporting this game into a bright future. Thank you four your hard work.

While most of the time I don't feel like I know what I'm doing, it's hard not to be drawn in by the wonderful almost toy-like visuals of this game and world.

Everything seems hand crafted, and lovingly designed. It's a wonder to behold.

I killed a goblin that was carrying an exploding bolt crossbow. I know how an exploding bold crossbow, and I have learned that many more items are destructable in the game than I had first imagined. Additionally, I learned that stones (which look like props) actually have ore and stuff inside of them. Nice surprise.

Another really cool feature I noticed is that any enemy that you fight will drop any armor that they are wearing, also their weapons, and some additional loot. But it's cool to see that you get their actual items as loot. On top of that, you can break pieces of their armor off in battle, which is a nice little touch.

Right now, I'm not sure if I'm supposed to have a goal in the game, so I've set myself the goal of collecting bloody goblin hearts from all my victims.

Truth be told, I'm having a lot of fun with this game.

Early Access Review

Cute graphics + destructible enviroments + Hack and Slash 3rd person RPG similar to Dark Souls (but more casual)

Are you getting exhausted from playing games with a dark intimidating atmosphere that take themselves too seriously? Do you want to play a game that is easy to access and makes you smile and laugh without being too silly? Then Hardland is the game for you.

Hardland has a perfect balance between moderately challenging gameplay and the fun of exploration and looting. This game was not designed to challenge your skills, but rather it was designed to make you smile. And guess what... we all need to take a break sometimes and enjoy something goofy, right?

In the Early Access version, you start with a default warrior character who gains experience by killing creatures (and completing some quests). There is no skill tree at this point. Gaining levels will simply improve your health and damage and allow you to equip higher level items. Simple and straightforward.
Most environmental object can be destroyed (except very large objects like trees and buildings) and almost always contains something you can use including gold, simple weapons and healing items.

So you can see the game has some sandbox and open-world features. The only thing that would complete the picture would be a skill tree and crafting system, preferably the latter. I'm not sure if these are being planned or not, but they would definitely make the game a more decent experience.

But the most amusing features in this game would be:
the wacky enemies and the items that you can loot from their corpses.
You can kill merchants (or zombie merchants) to take their guns. You can kill a skeleton wearing a chicken mask to take his mask that allows you to attract chicken. You can kill a goblin to take his enchanted hammer or axe. Everything you see can be yours if you can take it by force! This makes you want to explore and find MORE enemies to destroy and loot. That would be the most fun feature of the game right now.

The combat itself is nothing too special. You can exploit the enemy's blind spots and just mash the attack button until they're dead. Not too challenging, they will always hit you the exact same way, very predictable. And their hit detection is not great. Perhaps this will be improved in the future?

So as you can see, there is lots of potential and lots of room for improvement. They need to add more NPCs, the quests have to be elaborated more, the quest bugs must be fixed. The map needs to be made more clear (I can't find the entrance to a dungeon using the map). The enemies must be made more challenging.
One annoying thing right now is that every time I try to help the town guard fight an enemy, if I attack the guard ONLY ONCE BY MISTAKE >> he will chase me and try to kill me non-stop!
Of course, there is no crime system right now, so you can pretty much kill all guards outside the town and no one would care.

If you like the concept based on this description, feel free to support the developers and buy it now. This is a good game to buy for your kids if you are introducing them to the 3rd person RPG genre (particularly if they are less than 12 years old), but it's also ok for your own casual game requirements. Otherwise, just keep your expectations to a healthy minimum until the full release.
Early Access rating : 7/10

Having bought into this game in the very early access, I was pleasantly surprised by the large, seemingly procedural world and emergent storyline that brought with it. While the art direction wasn't and still isn't my cup of tea, it seemed to have great potential if expanded on and better optimized. With this in mind, I decided to wait a few months and see what the devs would come up with given time.

Imagine my surprise then when I downloaded it again mid-year, only to find it had not only failed to improve in practically every aspect, but even regressed. Gone was the vast open world I'd enjoyed, replaced short chain of miniscule pregenerated maps and an endless, empty dungeon. Removed was the feeling of exploration and progression, the excitement and fun replaced with a struggle to progress anywhere that felt far more like a chore. The devs have promised to expand upon the existing game in the past few months, but so far the best they've managed is to shoehorn in a handful of mechanics that were in the original draft.

Elephant people and elven wizards aside, their focus on prettier graphics and visual effects over replay value and depth will ultimately lead to just another average mid-tier indie RPG. Assuming they stay the course with their new design plan, I can't recommend this game over the plethora of other such games available on steam.

What a great little game!

A wonderfully unique art style which reminds me of Tim Burton and Wallace & Gromit, an absolute pleasure to behold all of the lovingly sculpted houses, characters, and environment!

The enemies and environment vary sufficiently to keep me interested in them, the physics is a welcome feature, and the ground can be sculpted by explosions and magic impacts... very cool.

The armour system is quite unique... on top of the usual durability points commonplace in RPGs, you will also find that pieces of armour can fly off when struck in combat! AWESOME

The game was £10.99 when I bought it, this is fair I feel, considering the level of polish and content so far. So no criticism about the price.

The only real criticism I have is currently the lack of narrative/story, and the lack of a tutorial system to ease new players into the game. While I realise this is in beta, it is not a trump card that can be played to excuse shortcomings.

To wrap it up this is one of the most promising and unique RPGs I have seen in recent years. The charming art style, lovingly crafted locations, and good difficulty all provide a very solid foundation for what could be one of my favourite casual RPGs of all time. I really look forward to seeing future content they introduce to the game

These guys know where it is at. This game plays seemlessly, loads quickly, and the melee combat is challenging. Not much content as of yet, I played through most of what was there in less that 5 hours, but from what info I have collected thus far the game is updated quite frequently. The game is early access and I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND IT. If the game continues as it has progressed up till now It will definately be a fun game when they finish it. They expect to finish it soon (eta sometime 2015), however they have left it open to modders to tinker a little bit. In short, if there is something you don't like come release, we can always make it better ourselves.

The following is some pros/cons/scrutinies towards how my experience so far has been.

PROS:
Every melee fight is difficult, not because things have tons more health than you, but because the hitboxes are so precise that it takes a little while to get used to. Good thing the computer has the same problem. Ex: Zelda OoC-like playstyle.
Quests are straightforward and usually localized - Meaning you dont have to trek across the world 40 times to pick up some idiot's hat he left in some dungeon.
Updated frequently - every week or so come back to check out the new stuff they have added.
Plenty of weapons and all weapons have prefixes to change their damage or give them some cool visual effect.

Did you ever enjoy tht feeling of running though a town smashing boxes and pots in a Zelda Game? Well now it's barrels. and lots of them. Have fun! CONS/General Scrutiny:
The prefixes for weapons are there, but the effects on the weapons are minimal at best. Gold value for the prefixes is wierd too. For example: The Crossbow" is worth around 1000 gold. While the "True Crossbow" is worth around 600 and the latter does more damage. What?

You beat people with wands and they do rediculous amounts of damage. What? Some sort of magic in future updates?

Random drop chance items. --> I picked up the a "SPECIAL CROSSBOW" (explosive bolts) from the first enemy I encountered. Which Made the game really a point-and-shoot vs an actually difficult game.

On to the subject of crossbows
date: I would really like to see some sort of aiming requirement to shoot them.
